abstract: Editorial praises agreement between New York City Council and Mayor Michael R Bloomberg on four-year budget outline; holds that quiet, efficient negotiations that led to agreement represent height of fiscal responsibility--example that New York State Legislature should have mirrored long ago
title: EDITORIAL; The Wrong Way and the Right Way

abstract: Senator Charles E Schumer of New York takes uncharacteristically quiet stance on proposed changes to how Wall Street and banking industry conduct business; has said he will support proposed regulations and acknowledges that many financial institutions made mistakes because no one was watching and monitoring their transactions; Schumer's position is in direct opposition to that of New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, who says that proposed changes will negatively impact economic health of city; financial ties between Schumer and Wall Street outlined; photos (M)
geo_facet: [u'UNITED STATES', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK STATE', u'WALL STREET (NYC)']
title: A Friend to Wall St., Suddenly Quiet
byline: By CARL HULSE; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from New York.

abstract: Author Susan Cheever, who recently published new book Desire: Where Sex Meets Addiction, discusses her Manhattan home and newly found quiet life style; photos (M)
title: AT HOME WITH; A Writer Alone At Last

abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on quiet and unnoticed death of 'man in Apartment 2K' at East 19th Street in Ditmas Park section of Brooklyn; neighbors knew more about man's dog Chico than they did about him until he died, apparently of untreated wasting disease, and odor from body caused residents to call police; building was left with sense of mystery and dog, which neighbor Deborah Collins has since adopted (M)
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; In Apt. 2K, A Mystery Unresolved

abstract: Neighbors began to suspect something was wrong with Vincent Banescu, quiet elderly Romanian immigrant who was known in Brooklyn neighborhood for his 1975 Alfa Romeo Alfetta, when parking tickets began to accumulate on windshield; eventually his body was discovered in his apartment by building superintendent; photos (M)
title: A Quiet Neighbor, a Fading Sports Car, and a Death Announced by Parking Tickets

abstract: Changing demographic of New York City may best be demonstrated by growing number of complaints from apartment dwellers about noise made by neighbors' children; those called upon to intervene say vast majority of complaints are lodged by neighbors with no children or grown children, and often when family replaces especially quiet resident; parents are not presented with many good choices in New York unless they can afford house, but acoustical engineers are seeing boom in business from co-op buildings, which are increasingly taking preventive stance on noise control, particularly during renovations; photos (M)
title: The Noise Children Make

abstract: Quiet scene described on Manhattan's Automobile Row, on 11th Avenue from West 41st to 57th Streets, as sales plummet because of high gas prices and fears of recession; photo (M)9
title: WEST MIDTOWN; Traffic Sputters On Auto Row

abstract: Christopher Carter goes on trial in Manhattan Criminal Court on charges of assaulting Stuart Sugarman at Equinox gym because he allegedly could not take loud noises that Sugarman made during exercise; unidentified gym instructor testifies that he asked Sugarman to quiet down; participant in spin class says that Sugarman told Carter to make him quiet down during argument; photos (M)
title: Grunting in East Side Gym Class Leads to Hospital, and to Court

abstract: Article on quiet scene at once-thriving La Marqueta, outdoor market under railroad tracks in heart of Manhattan's East Harlem that has defied repeated attempts at revival; photos (M)
title: EAST HARLEM; Hope Amid the Plantains

abstract: Manhattan doorman Richard Melnick works on historical books about Queens during quiet times on duty; is president of Greater Astoria History Society; photo (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'UPPER EAST SIDE (NYC)', u'QUEENS (NYC)']
title: Door Keeper On 79th St. Keeps Stories Of Queens

abstract: Detectives are searching for gunman who shot and killed Chelsea Frazier and wounded her boyfriend, Carlos Cruz, while sitting in their car on quiet street in Bronx; couple's infant son, who was with them, was not harmed; Cruz tells investigators that he and Frazier and their son drove from Southbridge, Mass, for day of shopping in Bronx; photo (M)
title: Hunting for Answers in Fatal Bronx Shooting
byline: By AL BAKER; Reporting was contributed by Christina Crapanzano, Colin Moynihan, Sharon Otterman and Carolyn Wilder.

abstract: Readers suggest quiet places in answer to question Where Do You Find Peace in New York? (S)
title: Comments of the Week

abstract: Voters in New York Metropolitan area break free of traditional obscurity as they participate in what has been described as national primary; many describe race as exciting; despite overall energy, day feels quiet in some precincts; scenes in several voting venues described; photos (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW JERSEY', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK STATE', u'CONNECTICUT', u'NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA']
title: Area Voters Savor Rare Feeling: A Suspenseful Primary

abstract: Mourners gather in Bronx for quiet funeral of Virgilio Cintron, whose friends were charged with using his corpse to attempt to cash Social Security check; photo (S)
title: AFTER A DEATH THAT MADE HEADLINES, A QUIET FUNERAL

abstract: The Hunt column on search by Michelle Panzer and Paul Campbell for quiet apartment in Brooklyn with no upstairs neighbors; found top-floor two bedroom condominium on Third Avenue near Atlantic Avenue for around $738,000; photos (M)
title: THE HUNT; Quiet on the Home Front

abstract: Passengers and deckhands enjoy quiet, peaceful ride on State Island Ferry on Dec 25; say it is one of few days when ferry is not crowded and people do not seem rushed; photos (M)
title: A Day for Peace (and Quiet) on the Ferry
byline: By KEN BELSON and NATE SCHWEBER

abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column on quiet visit to New York City by Dalai Lama on way to receive highest Congressional civilian honor Congressional Gold Medal; says Congress is awarding medal despite China's warning of serious impact on relations with United States; photo (M)
title: NYC; A Hubbub Brewing Over the Dalai Lama? Not in New York

abstract: New York City Transportation Department, responding to noise complaints from residents of Little Neck, Queens, is seeking funds to build new railroad crossing or less costly barrier to qualify for 'quiet zone' and exempt community from blasts from trains along Long Island Rail Road tracks; photo (M)
title: LITTLE NECK; Trying to Shush Thomas the Tank

abstract: The Hunt column on search by Rosanne Ehrlich for quiet, pet-friendly apartment within commuting distance of Midtown Manhattan; found studio condominium for $360,000 on East 72nd St; photos (M)
title: THE HUNT; When Smaller Is Better

abstract: Growing number of homeowners seeking quiet living environment leads to increased number of acoustic specialists and products; housing design factors, outdoor noise and general environment of home are listed as possible contributors to excessive sound; David Skudin, president of CitiQuiet company that sells sound-insulating windows in New York City, says sales are up 50 percent from just two years ago; other sound specialists and homeowners describe challenges to creating quiet home; photos (M)
title: The Dream of Absolute Quiet

abstract: City Island residents look forward to some peace and quiet when New York City Police Dept closes nearby facilities where it has conducted target practice and all manner of ballistic and ordinance-related exercises since 1959; move of facilities, now at Rodman's Neck, to College Point, Queens, site of new Police Academy, will not happen for several years; photo; map (M)
title: City Islanders Ponder Future Without Gunfire Across Bay

abstract: Fedeal Aviation Adminitration chooses new flight pattern for airspace around New York City and Philadelphia; plan will ease delays but will also lead to noisy jets flying over some formerly quiet areas in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Delaware; could save airlines as much as $720 million a year (S)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK STATE', u'PENNSYLVANIA', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'DELAWARE', u'PHILADELPHIA (PA)', u'NEW JERSEY', u'CONNECTICUT']
title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Flight Plan Draws Criticism

abstract: Teresa Flores and Rufino Bedoya-Flores are charged with hitting and shaking their two-month-old son Sebastian to death at their apartment in Manhattan; say they were trying to quiet crying child (S)
title: Parents Held in Baby's Death After Saying They Shook Him
byline: By EMILY VASQUEZ; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting.

abstract: Waverly Inn restaurantand Death & Co club are examples of Manhattan spots choosing to be discreet to point of invisibility, signaling retreat from hectic nightlife of meatpacking district; they are in obscure locations and have secret reservation numbers and 'soft openings' that cater to insiders to create perception of exclusivity; trend suggests that small and quiet is in vogue; photos (M)
title: Come to Our Club. Or Not. Whatever.
byline: By ALEX WILLIAMS and MELENA RYZIK

abstract: Developers are increasingly working with neighborhood groups to forge so-called community benefits agreements in order to gain approval for major projects; deals usually contain wage and hiring goals as well as other concessions to quiet opposition; critics in New York City, where agreements are not tied to city contracts, are concerned trend may distort planning process when groups seek concessions that are unrelated to impact on neighborhoods; photo (M)
title: Square Feet; In Major Projects, Agreeing Not to Disagree

abstract: Explosions boom through quiet area of downtown Brooklyn after propane tanks ignite during roof work atop police precinct house, sending metal tubes like missiles into streets below; no one is injured; photo (S)
title: Explosions Atop Brooklyn Police Station Send Tanks Flying

abstract: Article on quiet emergence of New York City as world's primary clearinghouse for fast-expanding pool of very-low-budget movies; city, long a force in independent film world, is center of new generation of film producers and directors and is winning recognition for hundreds of pictures a year shown at local commercial and nonprofit film festivals; Robert De Niro comments on success of his TriBeCa Film Festival; photo (M)
title: New York: 'Little' Films Grow Big

abstract: Quiet residential revolution unfolds in Lower Manhattan with thousands of new people, including young families, moving into old and new commercial buildings in last three years, even as government and private sector try to lure business tenants; more than 30,000 New Yorkers live south of Chambers Street, up from some 15,000-20,000 in months before Sept 11 attacks; more than 9,000 office units are now apartments and new residential buildings are going up near World Trade Center, bringing with them gyms, schools, restaurants and Whole Foods Market; baby sitters push $700 strollers in area that is still nation's third-largest commercial district, after Midtown Manhattan and Chicago's Loop; rising residential prices contrast sharply with lagging commercial rents; graph; Regional Plan Assn president Robert D Yaro points out that residents and businesses flourished together in oldest part of New York for three centuries, until monoculture financial center took over in mid-twentieth century (M)
title: Baby Strollers and Supermarkets Push Into the Financial District

abstract: Profiles of Christopher DiMea and Nicole Pearce, couple charged with two-month spree of burglaries and fatal robberies in New York State and Connecticut; DiMeo and Pearce met after being released from prison and shared quiet relationship, troubled family histories and drug addiction; photos (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK STATE', u'CONNECTICUT']
title: Troubled Lives For Suspects In Killings Of Jewelers
byline: By PATRICK O'GILFOIL HEALY and CHRISTOPHER DIXON; Patrick O'Gilfoil Healy reported from New York for this article, and Christopher Dixon from California.

abstract: Ground zero has been ruled off limits to formal protest, but edges of scarred site have become place during convention week for people to act out stresses and strains that have become apparent as Republicans take over Democratic city; arguments ensue between delegates and group that is there to heckle them; mostly, however, it is quiet day near site, with respectful hush in evidence; photo (M)
title: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- GROUND ZERO; Republicans Decide to See for Themselves What the Terrorists Did
byline: By LESLIE EATON; Janon Fisher contributed reporting for this article.

abstract: Pres Bush's aides say he will present detailed second-term agenda when he is nominated, part of ambitious Republican National Convention program built on invocations of Sept 11 and efforts to paint Sen John Kerry as untrustworthy and out of mainstream; say they gird for extensive street demonstrations and will seek to portray all protests as Democratic-sanctioned displays of disrespect for sitting president; convention will offer national television audience more moderate face for Bush and party, with focus on 'compassion,' after months in which Bush stressed issues of concern to conservatives; Sen Zell Miller, Democrat estranged from his party, and Gov Arnold Schwarzenegger will lead prime-time televised lineup of speakers notable for absence of conservative leaders; Republicans are pressing for quick and quiet adoption of platform to minimize dissent over divisive issues; photo (M)
title: CAMPAIGN 2004: THE REPUBLICANS; Bush Promises Detailed Plans at Convention

abstract: Police provide few details in shooting death of 15-year-old Brooklyn (NYC) resident Larry Hill Jr, who was gunned down during basketball game at otherwise quiet Highland Park (NYC); photos (M)
title: Gunfire Kills A Teenager And Shatters An Oasis
byline: By MARY SPICUZZA; Oren Yaniv and Michael Wilson contributed reporting for this article.

abstract: College Point, Queens, residents bemoan flurry of building by developers rushing to cram as many homes as possible into what had been quiet and remote community before proposed zoning changes limit new construction; cite plan to build 86 two-family-homes atop 8.5-acre waterfront landfill that holds gravestones and other cemetery debris; New York State has quietly approved developer's plan to clean up site without informing neighbors, who raised environmental issues; photos (M)l
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK STATE', u'COLLEGE POINT (NYC)']
title: CITYWIDE; Discarding Gravestones And Burying the Waterfront

abstract: Editorial maintains that New York City will never be quiet, but that Mayor Michael Bloomberg is right to try to turn down volume with new noise ordinance
title: Shushing the Big City

abstract: Nabil al-Marabh, who was No. 27 on FBI list of terror suspects after Sept 11 attacks and boasted of plot to blow up fuel truck in New York tunnel, was returned to native Syria in January after completing eight-month jail term; quiet repatriation to country considered sponsor of terrorism was carried out even though prosecutors sought criminal case and judges openly expressed concern about Marabh's terrorist ties; Justice Department says some suspects cannot be tried without giving away infelligence methods (S)
title: Despite Fears Of Terror Tie, Suspect Goes Back to Syria

abstract: Correction of April 1 article about finding quiet apartment in Manhattan; Cityproof windows are $2,900 each
title: Corrections

abstract: Manhattan College and Seton Hall University, both of which are small, quiet Roman Catholic colleges removed from bright lights of New York City, move on to second round of NCAA tournament; photo (M)
title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL; Two Campuses Share Faith and Hoops
byline: By LYNN ZINSER and VINCENT M. MALLOZZI; George Vecsey, in Raleigh, N.C., contributed reporting for this article.

abstract: Residents of Tulfan Terrace, small street in Bronx (NYC) where many have lived for decades, have one by one agreed to sell their lots and their homes to developers who want to build high-rise building on their block; though many held out for long period of time, and ended up receiving large sums of money for their property, some still lament progress that will make this once quiet corner of county in city extinct; photos (M)
title: Quiet Street Reaps Price of Progress; Bronx Developer's Offer Wins Over Longtime Residents, One at a Time

abstract: Generations of New Yorkers have made do with basement apartments; some see basement as stopgap measure, others as gamble and still others welcome basement's quirky and quiet charm; apartments less than 50 percent above ground are considered cellars and most cellar dwellings are illegal; many basements can legally be converted for residential use; photos (M)
title: Be It Ever So Low, the Basement Is Often Home

abstract: Law enforcement officials in Queens say Nayquan Miller and Charles Bryant, both 16, murdered Huang Chen, 19, after they ordered food from Chinese restaurant so that they could rob Chen when it delivered it; youths are charged as adults; their friends and neighbors describe them as well mannered and quiet (M)
title: Slaying Is Called a Robbery Plot Gone Awry
byline: By ANDREA ELLIOTT; Oren Yaniv contributed reporting for this article.

abstract: Private garden of 1 Sutton Place, one of New York's most exclusive addresses, is verdant jewel that sits atop Franklin D Roosevelt Drive, on property that has actually belonged to city since it was taken by eminent domain to build highway in 1939; photos; site was then leased back to co-op for $1 a year, but lease expired in 1990, and co-op board has remained strategically quiet about lapse, even swearing prospective apartment buyers to secrecy; city has not tried to repossess property until now, when it is needed as part of highway rehabilitation project; Parks Comr Adrian Benepe is also suggesting creating public esplanade linked to adjacent parkland, which is not sitting well with socially prominent residents of 13-story co-op, built in 1927 (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'SUTTON PLACE (NYC)', u'FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT DRIVE (NYC)']
title: In Sutton Place's Backyard, Private Oasis on Public Land

abstract: Unexpectedly quiet scene at Imam al-Khoei Islamic Center in Jamaica, Queens, described in wake of capture of Saddam Hussein; Mohamed al-Mosawi, spokesman for Iraqi American Council, says fear is finished; photos (M)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA; For Iraqis in New York, A Quiet Hope Reigns

abstract: Review of year's notable ideas and developments on quiet parties, where people write notes instead of speaking; trend was started by Paul Rebhan after searching in vain for bar in New York with ambient noise low enough to support actual conversation; photo (M)
title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Quiet Parties

abstract: Blocks, bars and shops around Yankee Stadium (NYC) from October to April are quiet and decidedly unrowdy, which is great contrast to environment during baseball season; photos (M)
title: Quiet Time In the Bronx; In Fall, After the Yankees Go Home, The Streets Show a New Character

abstract: Dan Barry column on late Sister Kathy Toner, Roman Catholic nun who founded Samaritan House, small nonsectarian shelter in Brooklyn for homeless women and children; notes that Sister Kathy lived in shelter for nearly 15 years, until failing health forced her to move to a convent in Scranton, Pa; says it is typical for many of nuns who have led unheralded lives of good works in New York to spend quiet retirement in home far from city (M)
title: About New York; Muted Finale To a Life Played Like a Sonata

abstract: Cabinetmaker Patrick Eck finds peace and quiet in South Bronx loft, where his home and studio are located; photos of renovated loft (Currents column) (S)
title: CURRENTS: HABITATS; In the South Bronx, Peace and Quiet in a Loft of One's Own

abstract: John Paris letter says World Trade Center memorial should be placed on top of new, stronger towers as quiet place for meditation and respect, but not at ground level because that is where life goes on
title: Grand Visions at Ground Zero

abstract: Some family members of Sept 11 victims opted to spend some quiet time at bottom of ground zero site, remembering loved ones rather than dealing with crowds that gathered on second anniversary of attacks on World Trade Center; photos (M)
title: A Day of Quiet Remembrance at Ground Zero

abstract: Reminders of terrorist attacks that staggered nation two years ago are scarce in Miami Beach, Fla; here, and in many other parts of nation, people cling to familiar rituals and schedules, commemorating anniversary in quiet ways or trying not to think of it at all; photos (M)
title: TWO YEARS LATER: COMMEMORATIONS; In Public and in Private, A Nation Pays Tribute

abstract: New York Fire Department will transfer 20 firefighters with most sick leave absences to less busy firehouses in effort to stem abuse of medical leave; hopes move will afford firefighters less opportunity to get hurt on job; assignment to quiet firehouse is akin to direct attack on firefighter's pride; Uniformed Firefighters Assn says move sends wrong message (M)
title: The Biggest Users of Sick Leave Face Transfer in Fire Department

abstract: New York City Charter Revision Commission approves measure to be placed before voters in Nov that would end political primaries for municipal offices and establish nonpartisan elections; move could pave way for most significant changes in city's elections in nearly century; nonpartisan elections are held in 41 of 50 largest cities in country; panel's vote sets stage for what is likely to be contentious and highly partisan campaign; Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, Democrat-turned-Republican, is champion of nonpartisan elections; his unlikely allies include Independence Party and one of its leaders, Lenora Fulani, former neo-Marxist; Republicans have been fairly quiet about where they stand on matter; those opposing nonpartisan primaries are leaders of Democratic Party and Conservative Party, most civic groups that monitor city government and even some labor unions (M)
title: PANEL COMPLETES PLANS TO REVAMP VOTING IN THE CITY

abstract: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, seeking to quiet rumblings that his administration allowed security to slip at City Hall, says he has increased security measures there in ways not noticeable to public; comments come two days after fatal shooting of Councilman James E Davis by political rival Othniel Boaz Askew; photo (M)
title: Bloomberg Says He has Improved Security at City Hall

abstract: Amtrak's Washington-New York has 'quiet car' on which cellphone use is not allowed, and tempers will fly if rule is violated; Dr Lawrence Schwartz has joined fellow Metro-North passengers to lobby MTA for quiet car, so far, to no avail; other passengers find cellphones indispensable and oppose quiet car segregation; photo (M)
title: BUSINESS TRAVEL; Sound, Fury and Cellphone Users and Abusers

abstract: Friends of Ousmane Zongo, who was gunned down by police officers during cd counterfeiting raid at New York City warehouse, say he was dependable and quiet; Zongo was unarmed when police fatally shot him (M)
title: Friends Recall a Gentle, Reliable Man

abstract: Residents of North Riverdale are on edge after three similar nighttime armed robberies within 10 days, all of them just off quiet Riverdale Avenue; local residents and business owners comment; police pay visits to businesses that stay open at night; photo (M)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NORTH RIVERDALE; Nighttime Robberies Put a Sleepy Neighborhood on Edge

abstract: Mark O'Brien, father of Burke O'Brien, 25-year-old man who was murdered during a robbery on Lower East Side, visits crime scene with his daughter, Carleigh; they also visit quiet block of tenements where Burke had been staying; photo (M)
title: Victim's Family Returns to Murder Scene

abstract: Police in New York and New Jersey seize 675 kilograms of cocaine worth about $61 million and arrest five members of Mexican drug gang that used house in Madison, NJ, to store drugs; seizure is said to be largest in Morris County and follows lengthy investigation; neighbors in quiet, upscale Madison comment; photo (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW JERSEY', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'MORRIS COUNTY (NJ)', u'MADISON (NJ)', u'MEXICO']
title: Cocaine Trove Filled House In New Jersey, Officials Say

abstract: Harlem neighborhood is quiet following police shooting of 17-year-old Allen Newsome; several residents say there has been no protest because Newsome was breaking law when he was shot; he had placed BB gun to head of police officer (M)
title: In Harlem, Response To Shooting Is Subdued

abstract: Bob Morris Age of Dissonance column describes quiet yet noisy Christmas Eve in New York City (M)
title: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; Enjoying the Quiet, Noisily

abstract: Seven teams of architects from around world unveil new designs for World Trade Center site; plans offer remarkable civic lesson on architecture and contemporary urban design aimed at mending hole left in Lower Manhattan by Sept 11 attack; designs include broad array of elements: quiet memorial gardens and scenic plazas in sky, soaring towers of bare scaffolding and sprawling canopies of glass; four include what would be tallest building in world; all set aside area for memorial to victims of 9/11; six designs submitted in July were scrapped; purpose of current exhibit and one in July is not to design buildings but to create land-use plan for site, setting location of office buildings, train station, memorial and new streets; land-use plan will be released by Jan 31; commercial considerations are expected to be large and perhaps leading factors in determining what is built and when; effort is being overseen by Lower Manhattan Development Corp, joint city-state agency; photos (L)
title: VISIONS FOR GROUND ZERO: OVERVIEW; 7 Design Teams Offer New Ideas For Attack Site

abstract: New York City City Council leaders are relatively quiet as Mayor Michael R Bloomberg lobbies for his proposal to raise taxes and cut services to close $1.1 billion budget gap; Bloomberg is expected to meet stiff opposition in Assembly and State Senate to his proposed tax on commuters; photo (M)
title: THE MAYOR'S BUDGET PLAN: OVERVIEW; Upstate and Down, Lawmakers Weigh In on Mayor's Budget

abstract: Basil A Paterson, once influential figure in New York City politics, now practices law and has no plans to retire; Joyce Brown, homeless woman who was in limelight in 1987 as she fought New York City program to forcibly hospitalize her because of mental illness, no longer lives on streets and leads quiet life; photos (M)
title: FOLLOWING UP

abstract: Randy Master letter contends that New Yorkers should not use October as time of reflection now that New York Yankees and New York Mets are out of World Series, arguing that fans would still prefer to see their teams succeed than have quiet time (S)
title: Unacceptable

abstract: Mayor Michael Bloomberg administration has quietly set up 18 new homeless shelters across city for more than 1,200 families resulting in protests from neighbors and their political leaders; residents complain that shelters were opened with no notice and litle chance for public hearings; City Councilman James E Davis has introduced bill requiring agency for homeless to give local public officials 60 days' notice before building or acquiring shelter; many homeowners and other residents near new shelters say their quiet streets have been ruffled by annoying incivilities; other homeowners and residents say black and Hispanic areas are being singled out for shelters; map (M)
title: Bloomberg's Shift of Homeless to Hotels Alarms Some Neighborhoods

abstract: Article on films with war or terrorism themes, such as The Quiet American, Collateral Damage and Big Trouble, whose release dates have been pushed back as result of September 11 terrorist attacks; independent filmmakers are facing same problem and have delayed release of military comedy Buffalo Soldiers and The Grey Zone, a Holocaust drama; photos (M)
title: Films With War Themes Are Victims of Bad Timing

abstract: Pres Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe visits City Hall, sparking raucous display of 1960's-vintage pan-African sentiment despite efforts of Council leaders to keep it quiet; Mugabe and his host, City Councilman Charles Barron, attend reception with about dozen Council members, most of them black and Latino; many other Council members stay away from event; Barron aide says that visit fulfills Barron's promise to not only connect city neighborhoods with City Hall, but 'to bring mother Africa to the hall in which she belongs'; photo (M)
title: President of Zimbabwe Visits City Hall

abstract: Col John Perrone, commander of Guantanamo Bay prison, says many men in custody are aware of anniversary of attack; says prisoners were quiet as memorial observances were held throughout day (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'GUANTANAMO BAY NAVAL BASE (CUBA)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN']
title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: SOME MOMENTS -- Guantánamo Bay; Taps Is in the Air, Inmates in the Cells

abstract: Sean Boggs, who was in Lower Manhattan last Sept 11 when planes struck, spends morning in quiet reflection in corner of Central Park; ran there last Sept 11 from his job at World Trade Center (M)
title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: MOMENTS -- CENTRAL PARK; A Place for Solace

abstract: Many work places througout nation experience pauses in daily schedules as some planned and some spontaneous observances and moments of silence help workers cope with overwhelming emotions as Sept 11 is remembered one year later; employees everywhere dress in red, white and blue, or simply black; workaday atmosphere is more hushed than usual, with fewer telephones ringing and time for quiet reflection (M)
title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: THE WORKPLACE; As People Try to Work, Memories and a Hush

abstract: Anne Bernays letter on Sept 11 commemoration calls for quiet prayer or meditation, not orgy of emotionalism; photo
title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart

abstract: Many pilots plan to make anouncement on their flights asking for minute of quiet reflection on first anniversary of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; moment will be especially somber for crews and passengers on flights operated by American Airlines and United Airlines, which each lost two planes and people aboard them last year; American lost total of 4 pilots and 13 flight attendants in planes that crashed into World Trade Center and Pentagon; United lost 4 pilots, 12 flight attendants and 2 off-duty customer service agents in crashes at trade center and countryside near Shanksville, Pa (M)
title: Two Airlines Recall Those Who Were Lost

abstract: Editorial says mapping of World Trade Center victims by ZIP code underscores how may were highly paid members of financial firms; says that while this is just what common sense would suggest, it somehow feels like quiet revelation, as does almost anything that provides fresh glimpse into nature of Sept 11
title: Where They Lived

abstract: Letter from Mark Stuart Ellison says somber Sept 11 anniversary is best marked by quiet contemplation (Aug 11 article)
title: How to Mark Sept. 11

abstract: Some Lower Manhattan residents, overwhelmed by memories, fearful or just seeking quiet respite, are making plans to be away from neighborhood when city marks first anniversary of September 11 terrorist attacks; photo (M)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; Many Yearn to Put Some Distance Between Themselves and Their Memories

abstract: Exhibition of photographs taken in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington opens in Berlin, in show partly financed by Germany's Interior Ministry; opening is quiet event, with patrons moving silently from one image to another; show will travel to 14 cities across Europe, including Paris, London, Zurich and Stockholm (M)
geo_facet: [u'LONDON (ENG)', u'NEW YORK CITY', u'STOCKHOLM (SWEDEN)', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'ZURICH (SWITZERLAND)', u'PARIS (FRANCE)', u'BERLIN (GERMANY)']
title: Sept. 11 Photo Exhibition Touches a Nerve in Berlin

abstract: New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, since taking office six months ago, has taken quiet but significant interest in the arts, especially those in public spaces; his administration has borrowed sculptures from Museum of Modern Art for lawn at Gracie Mansion, and nine paintings and three sculptures on lona from Whitney Museum of American Art come rolling into City Hall for use in Bloomberg's office; more sculptures will soon go up in historic City Hall Park; Bloomberg revives arts awards that were rarely given after Mayor Edward I Koch left office, and he makes point of attending presentation ceremonies for them; Dept of Cultural Affairs receive among most gentle of cuts to city's budget this year, about 5 percent, compared with 7 percent to 15 percent cuts most agencies had to endure; photos (L)
title: Suddenly, It's Art For the City's Sake; Bloomberg's Hearty Embrace Signals A Whole New Approach at City Hall

abstract: Barbara Samide, principal of St Elizabeth's elementary school in Ozone Park, Queens, charges that parish's pastor, Rev John Thompson, had an 18-year-old gay lover living in rectory and lavished gifts on him that were paid for with school funds; says she brought situation to attention of senior diocesan officials at least two dozen times and was told to keep quiet; says she eventually went to prosecutors and was reprimanded by diocese for cooperating with them; is preparing sexual harassment suit, charging that Thompson verbally abused her and taunted her with pornographic material; Thompson has resigned at St Elizabeth's and is residing at St Gertrude's parish in Far Rockaway, where he celebrates Mass; photos (M)
title: Parish Shaken by Reports of Sexual and Financial Misdeeds

abstract: First Memorial Day since September 11 terrorist attacks is commemorated across New York metropolitan region with cheering crowds and quiet prayer; parades and other events in New York City described; Mayor Michael R Bloomberg attends ceremony honoring war dead with hundreds of veterans aboard aircraft carrier Intrepid; photos (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA']
title: A Memorial Day in the Long Shadow of Sept. 11

abstract: Internet grocery shopping makes quiet comeback, despite disappointing start and demise of many start-ups; Richard Tarrant of MyWebGrocer.com, company that designs and services D'Agostino's Web site, comments; photo (M)
title: Ordering Groceries in Aisle 'www'

abstract: American Muslims say events of Sept 11 continue to reverberate in their lives, in ways large and small; state and federal civil rights agencies are flooded with complaints from Muslims who contend their employers and co-workers openly denigrate Islam, label them terrorists and, in some cases, fired them solely because of religion or national origin; many other Muslims point to quiet but persistent discrimination against them in everyday social transactions; photo (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: RELATIONS; For Many American Muslims, Complaints of Quiet but Persistent Bias

abstract: Annual Kips Bay Decorator Show House features 16 rooms created by winners of competition; quiet, restrained design is featured in all rooms with little flaunting of wealth; decorators choose muted colors and uncluttered style; flashy electronics of recent years give way to bookshelves; materials used are soft and lighting is indirect or diffused; photos (L)
title: NEW YORK/MILAN; Designers Turn Down The Volume

abstract: Cable and broadcast news networks seem to have held much of very large audiences that tuned in after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; news executives say they are unsure whether growth will hold if domestic terrorism front remains quiet; news audiences are still far smaller than in first weeks after attacks, when up to 50 million people may have watched news; graph of audience gains; photos (M)
title: MEDIA; Audience for Cable News Grows

abstract: Following Up column; Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn, who in 1968 became first black woman elected to Congress, is now 77 and leading 'quiet life' in Florida; William E Tager is serving sentence for killing NBC stagehand Campbell Theron Montgomery, and is eligible for parole in 2007; photos (S)
title: FOLLOWING UP

abstract: Sex abuse case in Brooklyn Diocese, and others, shows tension between church officials who say they are handling cases fairly and conscientiously, and victims and others who say church is mostly interested in keeping abuses quiet; in Brooklyn, three nuns came forward in 1996 with reports that three priests sexually abused adolescent boys in parish 20 years before; nuns were assured diocese would act aggressively, but diocese never informed them or victims of its action, and diocese decided not to notify law enforcement officials when one of priests admitted to sexual abuse of boys; diocese says it has no responsibility to inform nuns of its actions, and that victim never came forward; current wave of pedophile priest scandals has prompted dioceses around country to pore through old personnel files; many are turning over names of priests from long-gone cases to prosecutors, but no diocese in New York metropolitan area is doing so; bishops in Rockville Centre and New York have signaled willingness to report new cases to authorities; current New York law does not require church officials to report sexual abuse allegations; photos (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK STATE', u'NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA']
title: Bitterness in Brooklyn Diocese Over Abuse Case

abstract: Appeals Court grants temporary stay of sentence to petty thief sentenced to 10 months of home detention with no TV; Judge Alvin K Hellerstein of Manhattan, in sentencing Edward Bello, said he wanted Bello to think about his long string of arrests and his punishment in quiet periods; Bello's lawyers maintain that depriving Bello of television violates his First Amendment rights and cuts him off from important news events; Bello says he is grateful that Judge Hellerstein allowed him to stay out of prison but that television is vital part of his life; photo (M)
title: A Sentence of No TV? Unusual, Yes, but Cruel?

abstract: Profile of Albert Schussler, 85-year-old tax consultant at center of city's alleged $10 million tax-assessment bribery scheme; people in real-estate industry say that there was nothing flashy about Schussler, that he was quiet, knowledgeable and down to earth; photo (M)
title: Smart, Generous, Low-Key And Indicted in Bribery Plot

abstract: Excerpts from new NYC guidebooks: New York's 50 Best Places to Find Peace and Quiet by Allan Ishac, The Girl's Guide to New York Nightlife by Daniella Brodsky and Gerry Frank's Where to Find It, Buy It, Eat It in New York; photos (M)
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/GUIDEBOOKS; Places to Meditate or Drink From a Fishbowl

abstract: Eleven Afghan women living quiet lives in exile in United States are suddenly in limelight now that war in Afghanistan has called attention to medieval treatment of women under Taliban; meet at White House with Laura Bush, dine with United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, take part in Congressional hearing and attend party at home of Donna McClarty; also get training in how to present selves in now regular interviews with reporters; were brought together by Vital Voices Global Partnership, which promotes women's leadership around world; photo (M)
title: Afghan Women Trade Shadows for Washington's Limelight

abstract: US airports are unusually quiet as many Americans use other means of travel to get to Thanksgiving destinations; lines at security checkpoints are exception; photos (M)
title: Airports Sleep Through Chase for the Turkey

abstract: Ottilie W Lundgren's death from anthrax baffles investigators who have descended on town of Oxford, Conn, to determine how elderly woman living quiet life of pleasant routine contracted deadly infection; photo (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIM; A Fan of Mysteries Is Now at the Center of One
byline: By WINNIE HU with AL BAKER

abstract: Anthrax attacks have brought heightened scrutiny to Dr Theresa Koehler's laboratory at University of Texas Medical School, Houston, and other domestic laboratories where anthrax is stored; Koehler, anthrax researcher used to quiet obscurity, has found her life upended; tight security prevail at lab; photo (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH; At an Anthrax Lab, the World Changed Quickly

abstract: Several dozen top Hollywood executives are set to meet with Karl Rove, Pres Bush's senior adviser, to try to find common ground on how entertainment industry can contribute to war effort, replicating in spirit if not in scope the partnership formed between filmmakers and war planners in 1940's; conflict provides opportunity for studios to reassert their patriotism and perhaps quiet some of anti-Hollywood clamor among conservative elements of country, and it could also be good business (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FILM INDUSTRY; White House Takes Steps To Renew Tie To Hollywood

abstract: Correction of October 28 article on sense of quiet in New York City museums and other public places, which misstated location of Museum of Jewish Heritage; it is in Battery Park City (S)
title: Corrections

abstract: Erika Kinetz essay describes brief interludes, in aftermath of September 11 attacks, when lost New York, livable place with quiet museum galleries and uncrowded sidewalks, returns; photo (M)
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Lost City, Reborn for Now

abstract: Political factors seem to have made front lines 35 miles north of Kabul one of least bombed places in Afghanistan, spurring soldiers to flee to front for quiet night before driving home in morning; rebel commanders complain Taliban has been allowed to reinforce lines at front; lack of American bombing at front deters Northern Alliance from taking Kabul before accord is reached on makeup of new government (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BATTLEFIELD; For the Moment, All Quiet On the Northern Front

abstract: Mohamed Atta's path to Sept 11, pieced together from interviews with people who knew him across 33 years and three continents, was quiet and methodical evolution of resentment that somehow took leap to mass-murderous fury and to his coordination of worst terrorist attacks in history--on World Trade Center and Pentagon; photos (L)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MASTERMIND; A Portrait of the Terrorist: From Shy Child to Single-Minded Killer
byline: This article is based on reporting by Neil MacFarquhar, Jim Yardley and Paul Zielbauer and was written by Mr. Yardley.

abstract: Article notes reaction in Arab world to American-led military attacks on Afghanistan; Saudi Arabia is quiet, even though it has broken ties with Taliban, fearing fallout that may come with taking position (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'SAUDI ARABIA', u'WASHINGTON (DC)', u'AFGHANISTAN']
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REGION'S REACTION; As Anger Smolders in the Streets, Arab Governments Temper Remarks, or Say Nothing

abstract: Israeli officials offer strong but quiet support for attack on Afghanistan; Palestinian reaction is ambiguous (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: JERUSALEM; Israelis Offer Help and Quiet Support for U.S.

abstract: Dennis and Martha Voutas Donegan leave two-bedroom rental in Manhattan and buy house in Belle Harbor, Queens, so they can raise their daughter in place of peace and quiet; photos (Habitats column) (M)
title: Habitats/Belle Harbor, Rockaways, Queens; Trading Manhattan Buzz For Beach and Boardwalk

abstract: Kabul, Afghanistan, is quiet, as people speak in hushed voices about what lies ahead and those who can afford escape have left; rumors of forced Taliban conscription abound and some who left immediately after Sept 11 terrorist attacks return because their money has run out (M)
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: REFUGEES; Afghans Are 'Looking At the Sky, Watching'

abstract: Terrorist attacks on New York and Washington have had enormous impact on quiet Thiers, France, where they are still constantly discussed; many residents back United States, but fear US response will worsen problem; French widely debate whether recent US behavior somehow spurred attacks; map; photo (M)
title: The War on Terror Finds Wary Support in France

abstract: Courthouses of Lower Manhattan are eerily quiet in week since terrorist attack on World Trade Center; courts are now officially open, but jury duty remains suspended in Manhattan, and many defendants are left in sort of legal limbo; many Lower Mamhattan cases are transferred to Midtown Community Court (M)
title: Courts Reopen to Echo of Silence, Instead of Gavels

abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel says that he will try to help Bush administration draw Arab nations into coalition against terrorism by permitting truce talks in Jerusalem, but only if cease-fire creates 'absolute quiet' for 48 hours beforehand; says that in exchange for cease-fire order from Yasir Arafat, he would instruct army to halt incursions into Palestinian territory; Arafat says he would met Israelis at any time, but he does not say whether he would order militants to stop fighting; his planned meeting with Foreign Min Shimon Peres was canceled by Sharon, who claimed such a meeting now would 'legitimize Arafat as a good guy' even as he is 'using terrorism' at fullest strength; photo (M)
title: Israel Wants Cease-Fire To Precede Truce Talks

abstract: Political pressure to do something--anything--to ensure that there is never a repeat of this week's terrorist attacks is immense on Capitol Hill; civil liberties advocates watch with quiet concern; across political spectrum, lawmakers argue that United States has entered new and more dangerous era that demands heightened security measures, including armed guards on commercial airliners and greater surveillance powers by federal agents (M)
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: CIVIL LIBERTIES; Some Foresee A Sea Change In Attitudes On Freedoms

abstract: Fourteenth Street in Manhattan is boundary between alive city to north, and eerie quiet to the south, where vehicles are banned in aftermath of World Trade Center terrorist attack; photo; only Chinatown manages some bustle; less than four percent of city's population lives below 14th Street, but its jumble of old streets contain outsize proportion of New York's restaurants, nightclubs and galleries (M)
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE SCENE; Below 14th Street, Silence but an Eerie Disquiet

abstract: New York City residents awaken day after terrorist attacks collapse twin towers of World Trade Center in somber and reflective mood; city seems more fragile and unfamiliar, and is mostly quiet; reassuring signposts of daily life are not there (M)
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MOOD; A City Awakes, Only to Reflect On a Nightmare

abstract: New York City residents awaken day after terrorist attacks collapse twin towers of World Trade Center in somber and reflective mood; city seems more fragile and unfamiliar, and is mostly quiet; reassuring signposts of daily life are not there (M)
title: AFTER THE ATTACK: THE MOOD; A City Awakes, Only to Reflect On a Nightmare

abstract: Article notes that racial makeup of Canarsie section of Brooklyn has changed more dramatically than any other neighborhood in New York City, with black population growing to nearly 60 percent in 2000 census from 10 percent in 1990; Caribbeans who have moved in were attracted to affordable single-family homes with yards, good schools and quiet sense of community; residents note that white families sold their homes quickly when blacks moved in (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'NEW YORK CITY METROPOLITAN AREA', u'CANARSIE (NYC)']
title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Canarsie, Brooklyn; 'For Sale' Signs Greet Newcomers

abstract: Editorial questions what Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani will get in return for healthy pay raises and promises of no layoffs in proposed new contract for members of District Council 37; says accord fails to require more productivity from union members in return for pay raises; calls this serious lapse that departs from mayor's professed goal that pay increases be offset by productivity gains; says since Giuliani leaves office next year, this issue should be addressed by mayoral candidates, who have thus far been quiet on subject
title: A City Workers' Contract

abstract: Unidentified man files suit against New York City, contending that police who searched and arrested him for drug possession in 1999 threw away syringe he got from needle-exchange program and card showing that he was enrolled in program; New York carved exception to its drug paraphernalia laws to curb spread of HIV and hepatitis from needle sharing; suit against New York City, and similar case in Connecticut, contend that exception is often ignored by officers on street; people who run needle exchanges hope litigation will stop arrests of people who use them; also hope court intervention will quiet addicts' fears of using exchanges, because consequences of one shared needle can be staggering (M)
title: Addict's Suit Claims Police Ignore Needle-Swap Law

abstract: Upper Manhattan has feel of quiet wintry village with snow-capped houses following blizzard that dumped many inches of snow on city; residents of Marble Hill Avenue seem unfazed by storm and its aftermath; photos (M)
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 2000: THE SCENE; Neighborhood Harmony, a Shovel at a Time

abstract: Quiet jackhammer may be in New York City's future; Raptor is helium-driven gas gun that can cut through six-inch concrete with nail-like projectiles nearly as fast as mile a second; its inventors say it is 25 percent faster than jackhammer, safer and easier on workers because it rests on ground and is operated remotely; Raptor (Rapid Cutter of Concrete) is honored by Popular Science Magazine as one of year's 100 most significant technological innovations; photo (M)
title: Lab Invents a Jackhammer That New Yorkers May Be Able to Sleep Through

abstract: Eating Out reviews of some Manhattan restaurants where one can have a quiet conversation; map (M)
title: EATING OUT

abstract: Article on quiet, springtime renewal of keys that allow select number of Gramercy Park residents and institutions access to gated park; photos (M)
title: URBAN TACTICS; Exclusive Key Club Quietly Renews Its Membership

abstract: Interior of Manhattan island seems nearly vacant on July 4th; zero-tolerance policy on illegal fireworks helps keep area quiet (M)
title: SALUTING THE FOURTH: THE SCENE; In the Sky, an Eerie Silence

abstract: Steven Cohen letter says compromise should be reached so that Central Park can accomodate both lovers of noise and of quiet (May 29 article)
title: A Park to Stir Me, and Soothe You

abstract: Ryoko Chosa, Japanese woman who worked as music promoter, is shot to death as she walks home on quiet street in Elmhurst section of Queens; photo (M)
title: Woman, 24, Shot to Death Near Her Home in Queens

abstract: Homeowners along Wilkinson Avenue in Morris Park section of the Bronx consider asking New York City to 'demap' their street, to get rid of rowdy intruders who congregate on quiet street at night; photo; map (S)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORRIS PARK; All Fed Up, A Street Talks Of Secession

abstract: Plan to recruit summer school teachers in New York City, which began as quiet negotiation, sets off power struggle pitting administration of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani against teachers' union and interim schools chancellor Harold O Levy; Giuliani opposes plan, proposed by Levy, which would provide cash bonuses of up to $1,500 for every certified teacher agreeing to work and domestic airline tickets to those in schools where students reach certain improvement goals; favors offering bonus pay, not airline tickets, and only to those teachers whose students show most improvement at end of summer program; union officials see summer bonus pay as precedent-setting wedge for initiating merit pay for individual teachers, concept union strongly opposes which argues it would set up unhealthy competition between schools; photo (M)
title: Battle Erupts Over Bonuses For Teachers

abstract: Boynton Avenue, Bronx, residents describe Malcolm Ferguson, unarmed man who was killed by plainclothes officer Louis Rivera, as quiet, easygoing man who never carried weapons and took to selling drugs as last resort in difficult life; photo (M)
title: Police Saw a Drug Criminal; Neighbors Saw a Quiet Man

abstract: Real estate developer Abe Hirschfeld is found guilty of contempt of court for violating NYS Supreme Court Justice Harold Beeler's order to keep quiet about his trial on charges that he tried to have his partner killed (S)
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Hirschfeld Is Guilty Of Violating Gag Order

abstract: Brooklyn Bridge Park Development Corp, nonprofit group financed by state Legislature, is holding workshops to hear local views on design and uses of Brooklyn Bridge Park; photos; map; long, thin site, stretching from Atlantic Avenue to beyond Manhattan Bridge, is surrounded by half dozen neighborhoods, each with own strong opinions; most nearby residents want quiet refuge and open space; chief designer Ken Greenberg comments (M)
title: Disparate Visions for a New Park; Accord Is Sought Among Clashing Views in Brooklyn

abstract: New York State Gov George E Pataki has remained quiet about New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani's holy war against Brooklyn Museum of Art and its shocking exhibition called Sensation, Pres Clinton's decision to offer clemency to imprisoned members of Puerto Rican nationalist group FALN that carried out bombing in New York City, and Senate contest between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Giuliani (M)
title: Political Memo; Furors All Around, But Pataki Lies Low

abstract: Two men are shot to death and two others wounded when they are attacked by group of as many as 12 men on relatively quiet street in Manhattan's East 20's; dead men are identified as William Quinones and Lateef Cobb; map (M)
title: 2 Killed and 2 Wounded in Shootings

abstract: Four New York City police detectives face charges in connection with beating of Brooklyn man, Reginald Bannerman, who fell to his death on subway tracks hour later; officers are accused of crimes including assault and tampering with evidence stemming from their 1997 confrontation with Bannerman outside Crown Heights restaurant; authorities say detectives became disorderly during party in restaurant, and attacked Bannerman when he tried to quiet them down; detectives are Mark Cooper, Orice Connor, Edward Howard and Lloyd Barnaby; photos (M)
title: Trial Set for Officers Accused of Assaulting Man Before His Death on Subway Tracks

abstract: Ophelia Upson, 84-year-old woman, is found bludgeoned to death, her body stuffed into kitchen closet of her home on quiet block in St Albans, Queens (S)
title: Woman, 84, Found Bludgeoned to Death

abstract: Photos of weekend fashion look in quiet section of Chelsea, new art gallery district in Manhattan
title: ON THE STREET; Chelsea's New Palette

abstract: Linda Newman letter scores use of loudspeakers at events in Central Park, contending park should be a quiet sanctuary, an escape from New York City's turmoil
title: Be Quiet in the Park

abstract: Major malfunction knocks out New York City's 911 system for more than an hour, crippling its ability to respond to emergency calls and raising questions about why it took so long for the backup system to begin working; while city officials express relief that shutdown was during relatively quiet Sunday morning period, authorities are investigating death of John Audy of heart attack at his Bayside home after his girlfriend was unable to get through on 911 call; Mayor Rudolph Giulianiand Police Comr Howard Safir comment; photo (M)
title: 911 System Breaks Down In New York

abstract: New York City buzzes along more or less as usual outside maze of police barriers in Times Square; inside barricades, another community, bustling but quiet, familiar but strange, enters its sixth day; security guard at Broadway store says street feels more like block party (M)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'TIMES SQUARE AND 42D STREET (NYC)']
title: In Shadow of Scaffolding, A Slightly Different World

abstract: Priests who know Msgr James E White express shock at news of his arrest on misdemeanor drug possession charges, saying it seems completely out of character for 50-year-old priest they describe as quiet and gentle; say his arrest is damaging to archdiocese, especially since New York has so few black priests in senior positions (M)
title: Priest's Arrest on Drug Charge Is Seen as Blow to Archdiocese

abstract: Pamela Turk, tourist from Florida, is shot in leg in midtown Manhattan by an apparently deranged man who was firing at homeless man who had asked him to quiet down; John S Palmer is arrested on attempted murder charges; photo (M)
title: Man Shooting At Another Hits Tourist In Midtown

abstract: Habitats column on Hudson View Gardens co-op apartment in upper Manhattan shared by Aaron Jay Kernis, Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, and his wife Evelyne Luest, pianist; couple needed room, and quiet, for their music; photos (M)
title: Habitats/Hudson View Gardens; Halls Are Alive With Pulitzer-Winning Music

abstract: Some residents of Duane Street are concerned about plans for sidewalk cafe that is planned for new upscale restaurant, called City Hall, that is scheduled to open in TriBeCa soon; they are worried that noise from sidewalk diners will disrupt street they call quiet and residential; photo (S)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA; Neighbors Fight 'City Hall'

abstract: William Grimes survey of New York City restaurants where diners can experience quiet and subdued elegance that once characterized drinking and eating in city; observes that as 1940's and 1950's recede from memory into myth, they have only gained allure, adding new luster to plush hotel bars, old-line restaurants like Le Grenouille, and Buick-weight classics like lobster thermidor; notes that at least three restaurants--La Caravelle, '21' Club, and Rainbow Room--have recently created separate sections on their menus highlighting classic dishes; photos (L)
title: RETRO IN NEW YORK; An Era Of Romance Shimmers In Revival

abstract: Abyssinian Baptist Church Pastor Calvin O Butts 3d, day after branding Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani racist, says he realizes that his policy of negotiating with city officials has failed, at least at City Hall; Butt's attempt at quiet diplomacy has long made him outsider to more outspoken black leaders; his uncharacteristic outburst against Giuliani has brought him more public criticism than praise (M)
title: With Attack on Giuliani, Pastor Returns to Fiery Past

abstract: Florence Fabricant Off the Menu column comments on Garrick, quiet restaurant in Mayfair Hotel, that serves French-accented food with Indian influences; notes Barbara Smith, owner of B Smith's in theater district, is opening B Smith's by the Bay on Long Wharf in Sag Harbor, NY; notes new restaurant ventures by Roberto Ruggeri and his partner, Stefano Frittella (M)
title: Off the Menu

abstract: My Manhattan article by writer Tony Perrottet about The Writers Room on Astor Place, where about 200 resident writers work in quiet individual booths; photo (M)
title: MY MANHATTAN; Where Writers Find Peace (Well, Sort of)

abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column describes Police Dept's terrifying invasion of apartment of quiet and law-abiding family in Crown Heights section of Brooklyn; says Police Comr Howard Safir later said raid was not a mistake, leaving inference that family was dealing drugs even though there is no evidence of this and nobody was arrested; claims such raids happen only in poor black and brown neighborhoods (M)
title: In America; Not Even Sorry

abstract: My Manhattan article by Francine Prose on austere, extraordinarily beautiful Friends Meeting House on Rutherford Place; describes teenagers from Friends Seminary settling into quiet contemplation during twice-weekly silent meetings; photo (S)
title: MY MANHATTAN; Teen-Age Meditation, Silent and Not

abstract: Year of the Tiger makes quiet entrance in Chinatown, with residents and merchants blaming Giuliani administration's ban on firecrackers for keeping revelers away; festivities in Chinatown and other Asian communities of city described; photo (M)
title: Chinese New Year Begins Without Its Usual Bang

abstract: Sean Carrington, first New York City policeman killed in line of duty this year, is remembered as a quiet man, not edgy, confrontational sort common in undercover work; fellow officers describe him as one of department's bravest officers who risked daily danger and stress of undercover narcotics work; photo (M)
title: Slain Detective Is Recalled as a Quiet Realist by Fellow Officers

abstract: Jewish Life Network, foundation backed by philanthropist Michael Steinhardt, has run into opposition to its plan to create Jewish cultural and social center for assimilated and upscale young Jewish people in brownstone it bought on West 67th Street; neighbors say it will worsen congestion on once-quiet street; noise from center's new air-conditioners and construction of wall blocking some of neighbors' light are also points of contention; photo (M)
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; A Fine Idea, All Say, but Too Big?

abstract: Richard Sandomir Sports Business column discusses New Jersey Devils owner John McMullen's proposal to move franchise to Hoboken; says New York Yankees owner George M Steinbrenner, who has been relatively quiet concerning possible move of his team from Bronx, can be expected to end silence and not allow McMullen to outdo him (M)
title: SPORTS BUSINESS; Memo to Steinbrenner: Watch the Devils

abstract: Quiet, steady transformation has brought broad occupancy gains to industrial property on three-mile stretch of Brooklyn waterfront designated Sunset Park In-Place Industrial Park; area includes major properties and spaces for small or even startup companies; map; photo (M)/
title: PERSPECTIVES; A Leasing Pickup on the Brooklyn Waterfront

abstract: Tight ban on fireworks makes for quiet Fourth of July in Chinatown and rest of lower Manhattan; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Fire Comr Howard Safir praise crackdown as reducing injuries and fires throughout New York City (S)
title: Police Ban on Firecrackers Makes for Quieter Holiday

abstract: Some Greenwich Village residents are disturbed by clanging of 'Old Jeff,' six-ton bronze bell atop Jefferson Market Library, which began ringing last December after century of quiet; photo (S)
title: A Bell Isn't Music to All Ears

abstract: Quiet upheaval among Orthodox Jews in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, occurs in recent community council elections; longtime leader Rabbi Joseph B Spielman and other board members were ousted; elected are younger community activists Michoel Chazan and Leibish Nash; Rabbi Spielman's remarks on community issues quoted; his photo(S)
title: New Generation Shakes Up Voting for Orthodox Council

abstract: Louis C Kibler letter on coming home from quiet country weekend of bird chirps to New York's cacophony of 4AM drunks, sirens, barking dogs and slamming doors (S)
title: Looking for Quiet? This Isn't the Place

abstract: Frenzied cross-fire breaks morning calm of quiet Queens neighborhood as masked robbers ambush two guards of payroll shipment, leaving security men--a retired police officer and off-duty detective--bleeding on sidewalk with more than dozen bullet wounds; robbers flee with at least $50,000; wounded security guards are Joseph Bellone and Arthur Pettus; photos; map (M)
title: 2 Guards Delivering Cash Are Ambushed and Shot in Queens

abstract: New York City landlords and developers, in five years leading up to current battle on rent controls, mounted quiet concealed effort to build their influence in state government through large increase in campaign contributions, with one of stated aims being to do away with rent laws; campaign has made real estate interests, always important figures in state politics, among biggest contributors to State Republican Party and Republican candidates for state office, including lawmakers leading bid to abolish most rent regulation; effort, illustrated by pattern of political contributions from property owners and their political action committees, discussed; chart (L)
title: Landlords Quietly Increased Donations to Fight Rent Law

abstract: Augustine and Ann Barry have been forced out of their quiet home in Hamilton Beach, Brooklyn, by noise and damage from temporary bridge erected just four feet away; photo; construction work on link to Howard Beach undermined home's foundation (S)
geo_facet: [u'NEW YORK CITY', u'HAMILTON BEACH (NYC)', u'HOWARD BEACH (NYC)']
title: Bridge Turns Man's Quiet Retirement Into 'Seven Plagues'

abstract: Editorial lauds quiet transformation over past decade of downtown Brooklyn, fueled by series of well-conceived joint public and private investments (S)
title: Booming Brooklyn

abstract: David Gonzalez (About New York) column discusses use of book Mr Ives Christmas, by Oscar Hijuelos, as primer of sorts for students at Union Theological Seminary to spark discussion that cuts across their academic disciplines and exposes them to idea of faith and ordinary people muddling through New York City, where random violence exists alongside private acts of devotion; book deals with heartbreaking life of quiet man whose son is murdered during holiday season; Hijuelos is invited to seminary to discuss book (M)
title: Townie Brings A Tale of Faith To a Seminary

abstract: Photos of quiet Manhattan streets on Jewish holiday of Rosh ha-Shanah
title: Quiet for the Holidays
